ref._text: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

title._text: Accepted Manuscript Visual Ranking of Academic Influence via Paper Citation Visual Ranking of Academic Influence via Paper Citation (a) (b) (c) (d) (e)
Accepted Manuscript Visual Ranking of Academic Influence via Paper Citation Visual Ranking of Academic Influence via Paper Citation (a) (b) (c) (d) (e)
Journal of Visual Languages and Computing

note._text: Received date: 20 July 2018 Accepted date: 16 August 2018

Please cite this article as: Zhiguang Zhou, Chen Shi, Miaoxin Hu, Yuhua Liu, Visual Ranking of This is a PDF file of an unedited manuscript that has been accepted for publication. As a service to our customers we are providing this early version of the manuscript. The manuscript will undergo copyediting, typesetting, and review of the resulting proof before it is published in its final form. Please note that during the production process errors may be discovered which could affect the content, and all legal disclaimers that apply to the journal pertain. ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D

p._text: Abstract-With rapid growth of digital publishing, a great deal of document datum has been published online for a widely spread of knowledge innovations, which is an important resource for human survival and social development. However, it is a time-consuming and difficult task to conduct a high-efficiency access of valuable papers from an extremely large document database. A set of ranking techniques have been proposed to evaluate the influence of articles by counting the number and quality of citations, such as PageRank. In fact, the influence of an article does not merely depend on the account of citations, which is also highly related to the citation network. In this paper, we propose a visual analytics system for visual ranking of academic influence of articles, based on an insightful analysis of citation network. Firstly, a characterization of articles is established through word2vec model, based on an analogy between the articles in citation network and natural language processing (NPL) terms. Then, the difference between articles in the vectorized space is employed to optimize the PageRank model and achieve desired influence ranking results. A set of meaningful visual encodings are also designed to present the relationships among articles, such as the visualization of high-dimensional vectors and time-varying citation networks. At last, a visualization framework is implemented for visual ranking of academic influence of articles, with the ranking models and visual designs integrated. Case studies based on real-world datasets and interviews with domain experts have demonstrated the effectiveness of our system in the evaluation of academic influence of articles.

Abstract-With rapid growth of digital publishing, a great deal of document datum has been published online for a widely spread of knowledge innovations, which is an important resource for human survival and social development. However, it is a time-consuming and difficult task to conduct a high-efficiency access of valuable papers from an extremely large document database. A set of ranking techniques have been proposed to evaluate the influence of articles by counting the number and quality of citations, such as PageRank. In fact, the influence of an article does not merely depend on the account of citations, which is also highly related to the citation network. In this paper, we propose a visual analytics system for visual ranking of academic influence of articles, based on an insightful analysis of citation network. Firstly, a characterization of articles is established through word2vec model, based on an analogy between the articles in citation network and natural language processing (NPL) terms. Then, the difference between articles in the vectorized space is employed to optimize the PageRank model and achieve desired influence ranking results. A set of meaningful visual encodings are also designed to present the relationships among articles, such as the visualization of high-dimensional vectors and time-varying citation networks. At last, a visualization framework is implemented for visual ranking of academic influence of articles, with the ranking models and visual designs integrated. Case studies based on real-world datasets and interviews with domain experts have demonstrated the effectiveness of our system in the evaluation of academic influence of articles.

head._text: Index Terms-Visual Analysis, Citation Network, Word2Vec Model, PageRank Model
A C C E P T E D

p._text: • Zhiguang Zhou, Chen Shi, Miaoxin Hu, and Yuhua Liu are all with School of Information, Zhejiang University of Finance and Economics. E-mail:{zhgzhou1983, ChenShi4066}@163.com, {humiaoxin, liuyuhua}@zufe.edu.cn.

There are several possible approaches studied for the ranking of articles , in which the citation relationship is always leveraged to evaluate the influence of articles. The account of citations is a most commonly-used metric , while some shortcomings still limit the accuracy of paper influence evaluation. For example, the difference between citing articles is ignored in the course of influence evaluation, which is ill-suited to compare the impact of papers in different scientific fields . Therefore, a citation network is often constructed with nodes representing papers and a directed link between two nodes representing a citation from a citing paper to a cited paper . A traditional evaluation model, PageRank, widely used in the ranking of webpage for Google Search, is applied to give higher weight to those articles cited by important papers and also weights citations more highly from papers with few references. Since the citation-based ranking methods cannot capture the dynamic nature of scholarly communications, many efforts have been made to employ novel relationships for the effective evaluation of article influence . Walker et al.proposed a new model named CiteRank , which introduced publication time into the PageRank model by exponentially distributing random surfers. Sayyadi and Getoor  defined a new measure, FutureRank, which calculated the future rank score of each article by utilizing citations network, authorship network and publication time. Yan et al.  provided P-Rank to examine the prestige in scholarly communication networks, by constructing a heterogenous scholarly network with various entities, including publications, authors, and journals. Wang et al.  built a heterogenous network based on multiple attributes and designed a PageRank & HITS framework to calculate the prestige scores of articles through a graph-based propagation algorithm of articles.

M A N U S C R I P T to retrieve related articles of high-quality from massive potential candidates, with the increasing scale of publications . Consequently, the evaluation of influence of academic articles has become an important research topic and received more attention. The account of citation is always taken as a key measure for the evaluation of the influence of articles . For example, a set of citation-based metrics have been proposed, such as H-index , gindex , and impact factor (IF) . Nevertheless, those articles with similar citation count will present different relationships and structure characters. As a traditional evaluation model, PageRank is used by Google Search to rank websites in their search engine . It is also widely applied for the ranking of influence of articles, accounting for the importance of the cited article in a self-consistent fashion . In the PageRank model, all citations are treated equally with the network structures of citing articles ignored. In fact, articles present different structures based on their citation relationships, and the influence will be better evaluated with the citation network taken into consideration . A set of ranking models are designed to achieve influence of articles based on their network topological structures . Cite2vec is designed to explore the semantic relationship of articles according to their citation contexts, without considering topological structures . It can be seen that the citation contexts of articles in the citation network might be an important clue for the optimization of influence ranking of articles.

In this paper, we propose a visual analytics framework for visual ranking of the academic influence of articles via citation context exploration. Different from cite2vec, we conduct the characterization of articles based on an analogy between the articles in citation network and natural language processing (NPL) terms. A commonly-used word2vec model is employed to transform the articles into high-dimensional vectors. Then, t-SNE is applied to project highdimensional vectors into 2D coordinates. The similarity between articles in citation network is evaluated based on the distance between corresponding points in the low-dimensional space, which is further taken as an influence weight to optimize the traditional PageRank model. In order to enhance the usability of the similarity of citation network and results of PageRank model, various visual encodings are designed allowing users to visually compare and analyze the article influence. A visualization framework is finally implemented to integrate the ranking models and visual designs, allowing users to easily focus on the ranking of articles of interest and intuitively capture the semantic relationship of citation network.
The major contributions of our work are summarized as followed:
• An analogy between citation network and NPL terms is established for the insightful exploration of semantic relationships of articles.

• A word2vec model is employed to represent semantic relationship of citation structures of articles, and the similarity between articles is further evaluated to optimize PageRank model for a desired influence ranking.

head._text: A C C E P T E D

p._text: • Several visual designs are integrated into a visualization framework, including citation network, similarity projection and ranking result, enabling users to easily extract and analyze the influence patterns of articles.

Visual Ranking is a traditional topic in the field of information visualization . Seo and Shneiderman  proposed a novel rankby-feature framework that presented a ranked list together with score visualization, enabling users to better discover features of interest among different variables. Behrisch et al.  addressed the comparison of multiple rankings by designing a small-multiple view of glyphs, which was defined as a radial node-link representation. Aiming at the comparison of a large set of incomplete and tied rankings, Kidwell et al.  defined a dissimilarity score on these rankings, which corresponded to the expected or average distance between the underlying permutations. The dissimilarity score was used to measure the similarity of rankings and visualized by means of multi-dimensional scaling heat maps. As the ranking results present obvious dissimilarities based on different combinations of attributes, a variety of interactive visualization techniques are designed for the ranking of multi-attribute data. Gratzl et al.  introduced LineUp to help users create and compare custom rankings by clicking and dragging columns to interactively adjust the attribute weights. Some systems are also implemented to generate rankings by augmenting the visualization of time series data . Xia et al. proposed a reader of Wikipedia, WikiTopReader, through which users were able to explore connections among pages with similar ranking trends . For large time series data, Qu et al. presented RankExplorer to visualize and explore both the value and ranking changes .

The rest of this paper is structured as followed: The related work is described in Section 2. Section 3 presents the system overview. The data transformation and weighted ranking model are detailed in Section 4. Section 5 shows the visual designs and the user interactions in the visual ranking system. Case studies are discussed in Section 6 and finally our conclusions are drawn in Section 7.
In this section, three kinds of related studies are described, including ranking techniques for article influence, ranking visualization and word embedding technology.

Word embedding has become an increasingly popular tool in the field of NLP. It can transform a word into a high-dimensional vector, which may represent the semantics of the word by some abstract means. Further, their semantic similarity can be measured by the distance between two word vectors . As a classical word embedding algorithm, word2vec defines a mapping between words and vectors through a neural network and constructs a computationally efficient model architecture to increase the quality of learned vector representations . The algorithm can be well applied in a series of tasks with help of the distributed representations of words trained with a skip-gram or CBOW model .

head._text: M A N U S C R I P T

p._text: Besides of NLP field, the word embedding techniques are also widely used in a variety of fields, based on the analogies between domain interactions and NLP terms . Cite2vec is an effective tool for the exploration of document collections, which takes citation contexts into account based on the word2vec model. The proximity of words and documents in a common embedding space is used to present their latent semantic similarity . Grover and Leskovec proposed Node2vec to help users capture the diversity of connectivity patterns in networks. A mapping between nodes and features is defined in a low-dimensional space, aiming at maximization of the possibility of preserving network neighborhoods of nodes . Inspired by word2vec model, transportation elements are transformed into words and sentences in a road2vec method, and the traffic similarity is measured by the cosine distance of road vectors, which is employed to the forecasting of traffic .

In our experiments, the datasets are obtained from an online scientific citation indexing service website, web of science (WOS), which provides access to multiple databases referencing cross-disciplinary researches. Currently, there are about 59 million records collected in the database of WOS, and the backfiles can date back to 1898. A set of important information of articles are provided, including journal, title, authors, keywords, citations, publication time and other details. To enhance the quality of data analysis, a familiar journal, IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics (TVCG), is selected to demonstrate the effectiveness of our method. It is a well-known and splendid journal, which publishes papers on subjects related to computer graphics, information and scientific visualization, visual analytics, etc. Our collection contains those articles published in TVCG from 1995 to 2018. In order to better extract the network structure, some citations are filtered out from the references, while those citation links may be retained when the cited paper is likewise published in TVCG. Approximately, the dataset consists of 3,108 articles with 8,600 citation links.

Inspired by the NLP technologies, we consider each article as a word, and the sentence can be constructed based on a context sequence of words, which represent a complete citation link, as demonstrated in . Then, we explore the influence between an article of interest and its reference through the context similarity calculated by word2vec model. Compared to traditional measures, PageRank model is a computationally simple and effective way to evaluate relative influence of papers and quantify their academic impact. It has been implicitly claimed that context of cited papers offers great supports for the analysis academic impact of papers . Thus, we further combine the PageRank model and word2vec model to propose a new optimized ranking algorithm. It brings context similarity of citation structure into PageRank model as a new weight, to obtain reasonable ranking scores of academic influence of articles.

The context similarity in the citation network tends to reflect how a paper is influenced by its cited papers. Accordingly, word2vec is employed to transform words into high-dimensional vectors, so that the proximity between vectors indicates the context similarity of citation.

head._text: A C C E P T E D

p._text: As mentioned above, sorting algorithms based on the PageRank model have been widely applied for the influence evaluation of academic articles. However, the context citation characteristics of articles are ignored, which bring uncertainties for the ranking result. Therefore, we design a visualization framework for the ranking of academic influence, optimizing traditional PageRank model with the semantic relationship of citation network taken into consideration. The system pipeline is shown in .

Firstly, inspired by the word embedding technique, a mass of articles and their citation relationships are recognized as NLP terms, like words and sentences. Trained by a word2vec model, the highdimensional vectors are obtained to present the semantic relationship of articles. Then, we use t-SNE to transform high-dimensional vectors into two-dimensional coordinates. The similarity of articles can be easily perceived in the two-dimensional space. Furthermore, we assign the influence weight to each citation link according to the similarity of citation network, and optimize the PageRank model for further influence ranking. The combination of word2vec and PageRank is able to help users extract and analyze the influence patterns of different articles effectively. Finally, a convenient user interactions of ranking are implemented to effectively correlate visual designs and ranking model to evaluate the academic influence of articles.

head._text: RANKING MODEL BASED ON CITATION NETWORK

p._text: In this section, we introduce an article ranking model, with the semantic similarity taken into consideration.

The citation network is composed of articles and their citation relationship. To preserve contextual relationship in the citation network, an analogy is established for the word embedding, through an efficient data preprocessing. First, each paper is regarded as a word. Then, a citation link is defined as (cited paper, origin paper), which is generated when a paper (cited paper) is cited by another paper (origin paper). Based on citation network, we suppose each sentence represents a complete citation link and the corpus is built and trained by word2vec model. For example, a paper A is cited by paper B, which is also the reference of paper C as shown in . Each sentence is represented as a sequence of words Se = (w 1 , w 2 , · · · , w i , · · · , w m ). The parameter m is the total number of papers in the complete citation link and w i is the ith word in the vocabulary.

As a predictive model, word2vec model has two common formats, the continuous bag-of-words model (CBOW) and the skip-gram model. Both models are employed for characterizing a word based on embedding vectors learned from its corpus . Compared with CBOW moedel, a skip-gram model usually has a better performance in the training of large datasets . As mentioned above, a large corpus has been established by a large amount of words and sentences, which provides enough training datasets. Therefore, the skip-gram model is suitable to train the context similarity of citation network. The skipgram model takes in a large sequence of words and assigns a vector in a high-dimensional space for each word, so that other words in local neighborhood contexts remain close to this word in the embedding space . The objective of skip-gram model is to maximize the average log probability :

where T is the length of training sequence, and k is the width of the training window. p(w t+i |w t ) is regarded as the probability of predicting w t+i according to a given word w t . . t-SNE is applied to project the high-dimensional vectors into 2D coordinates, with the semantic similarity largely retained in the projection view.
The new coefficient s i j is the influence factor that the paper i of interest gets from the cited paper j, representing their context similarity of citation network.

The above formula is used to express the probability of generating a background word w i with a given central word w j , where u w is regarded as the input vector of the w, and v w represents the input vector. The V is the number of words in the vocabulary . This symbol T represents the transposition operation. To optimize compute performance, Negative sampling is used as the softmax function in our model to calculate this probability.

• Step2. We use the weighted PageRank model to the citation network, with nodes representing papers and links between nodes representing citation relationships. The weighted PageRank model is presented as follows:

After the training process, a vectorized representation is obtained for each articles in the citation network. The cosine coefficients can be employed to measure the similarity between high-dimensional vectors , which will be further used to optimize traditional PageRank model.

where N is the total number of papers in the network (N=W). PR ′ (T i ) denotes the PageRank of node T i which has connection with paper J. C (T i ) denotes the number of outbound links to node T i , and d is a damping factor which can be set between 0 and 1.

p._text: In addition to citation count, our weighted PageRank model also takes network structure and their implicit semantic relationship into account. Especially, the semantic relationship of citation networks is important for the calculation of parameter s i j , which is employed to represent and analyze the different degrees for each paper influenced by their cited papers. Therefore, this model is supposed to perform well in the influence evaluation of papers.
In this section, a set of visual designs are illustrated including the projection view, ranking view and network view.

head._text: A C C E P T E D

p._text: In this section, we introduce a weighted PageRank model, enabling users to effectively extract and analyze the influence characteristics of different articles via their similarity calculated from word2vec model. In the optimized PageRank model, each article contains two attributes, such as citation list and similarity of citation structure. We build a network structure based on these attributes and utilize a weighted PageRank model to calculate the prestige scores of papers. The motivation is to make use of two kinds of information collaboratively, such as the citations and the similarity of citation structure. In fact, traditional PageRank model guarantees that citations from more important publications contribute more to the rank of the cited paper. Meanwhile, the similarity of citation structure is also significant for paper ranking in our model. Consequently, the weighted PageRank model is optimized through the following steps:

• Step1. Initially, according to the result calculated by word2vec technology, we introduce a new weight coefficient s i j , which is able to present the context similarity of citation structure between two papers.

t-SNE is a commonly-used method for dimension reduction , which performs well in retaining local and global structures in a lowdimensional space . To better present the context similarity characterizations of paper citation generated from word2vec, t-SNE is employed to reduce multiple dimensions (the maximum dimension is defined as 16 in the training process) of vectorized representations and visualize each paper with two-dimensional points. In the twodimensional space, papers are represented as blue points to present important characteristics, such as local clusters and correlations. The distance between each pair of points largely depicts the correlation of corresponding papers in the high-dimensional semantic space. The closer two points are located to each other, the more similar they present in the context of citation network. As described in , users can define an interactive area and select a group of points. The selected points are shaded in conspicuous red while the citing papers are shaded in conspicuous green. Users can also click a point after zooming in

is highlighted in red color. The papers cited in this article are connected with green lines. These papers links to their references with pastel pink lines. Analogously, those articles which cite the given article directly are linked with purple links, while the links between those articles and other citing papers are shaded in blue.

formula._text: s i j = ∑ n 1 (v i · v j ) √ ∑ n

p._text: A web-based system is implemented using Javascript, which supports a real-time exploration of visual ranking of the academic influence via paper citation, with the complex data transformation conduced in an off-line preprocessing phase. Several case studies and expert interviews are conducted to validate that our ranking method for academic influence is able to optimize the sorting result and describe the network structures of citation links.
Aiming at a validate evaluation of the effectiveness of our proposed system, a real-world dataset is obtained focusing on the journal of TVCG from WOS.
this projection view and its related properties will be displayed in the information view to help users to further achieve the characteristics of these articles.

head._text: M A N U S C R I P T

p._text: Ranking view is designed to visualize and explore the influence ranking of articles. Bar charts are used for ranking visualization and the length of each bar represents the prestige score of a given article. The vertical position of each bar encodes the rank of corresponding article, with the most highly ranked article located on the top of ranking list, as dispalyed in . In addition, we use colors to encode paper citation, as shown in . The corresponding bar of an article that the users are interested in and selected in the ranking list is shaded in red, while its directly citing papers are shaded in green.

It is an essential feature to help users track an article of interest by visually encoding rank changes within a ranking list. However, bar charts and color mappings are of limited assistance when analyzing differences between rankings . In order to address this problem, a steady and notable visual representation is required to help users intuitively observe the changes. Thus, a fundamental feature of our ranking visualization is the ability to flexibly compare the prestige scores calculated by given algorithms, as described in . Ranking view supports the comparison of two kinds of PageRank algorithms such as the traditional PageRank model and the weighted PageRank model. All articles can be sorted according to the prestige scores calculated by a model, while a curve obtained by the other model is plotted on the corresponding vertical position.

In our visual ranking system, massive interactions are designed to help users explore the rank of articles in academic influence. For example, users can obtain the different ranking list of articles by specifying parameters. As displayed in , when the damping factor d is 0.15, the article ranking first is shown with a much longer blue bar. When clicking it, there are more related characteristics displayed in different views. First, by observing these blue citation links in ranking view, users can found that the article has a great deal of citations and most of these papers which cite it has a lower rank. Then, the corresponding articles are highlighted by different chromatic points in projection view. Red point represents the article ranking first and it is close to the edge of these points . Most of green points are distributed around it. Similarly, articles and its citations are displayed in network view through colorized bars and links. Obviously, there are always some papers citing the article directly in recent years, even if its publication time is 1995 . Meanwhile, more details are listed in the information view, including its tittle, authors, keyword, publication time and PageRank scores, etc . Compared to the PageRank scores, it is evident that this paper always has high prestige.

head._text: A C C E P T E D

p._text: As the number of ranked articles increases, it is a cognitively demanding, error-prone and tedious task to explore the citation links in a bar chart and comprehend the network structures. It will be an effective way to communicate trends and relationships by encoding the values in a graphical representation by means of visual variables , such as position, length, and color, etc. In this section, we discuss how visual variables can be used to create our network view, enabling users to interactively analyze citation links of those articles of interest.

Firstly, multiple timelines  are aligned horizontally next to each other in chronological order from 1995 to 2018. According to their inherent property, especially publication year, articles are distributed on the corresponding timelines. For each timeline, bars represent articles that are sorted by the corresponding rank shown in the ranking view. Its length represents the corresponding prestige score. To extract the structure of citation network clearly, we search articles which have direct or indirect citation links with a given article, and then connect them by multiple solid lines. Simultaneously, we decrease the lightness of articles that are irrelevant to the given article for the reduction of visual clutters. As shown in , a given article As shown in , users can select several closer points (in ) which represents some similar articles based on the similarity of citation links, and displays their citation links in network view. Based on the key information shown in the information view, we found that they often shared common information, such as tittles, authors and keywords. For example, paper A and paper B share the same keyword, "minkowski sums". The topics of paper B and paper C are both about "collision detection". Paper A and paper B also share two authors. This commonality confirms the effectiveness of similarity evaluation result via word2vec. In addition, there is obviously no direct citation links between articles as shown in , even if they are quite close to each other in the projection view. We further observe their citation network carefully. Paper D and paper E form a group which is related to paper A, B and C directly or indirectly . Paper D is in the citation list of paper E which is cited by paper B . There are still some direct citation links between the group and paper A (or paper C) in  (or . It is evident that they still present similar features in the citation network. We can identify the similarity of citation directly by the distance of points in the projection view and further analyze their characteristics by comparing the citation links in the network view.

In this case, we study the difference between two kinds of ranking algorithms by comparing their visualization results. As shown in , the values of the weighted PageRank model are presented in the bar charts and the scores of original PageRank model are displayed by For example, we can find that there are obvious decreases in ranking scores of most articles, such as paper L (PR o =0.001339957, PR w =0.001135921, PT =2000) and paper N (PR o =0.000973907, PR w =0.000778042, PT =2006). The PR o scores of articles are high, but their PR w values become smaller. Besides, the PR w values of paper M improves slightly, resulting in a considerable increase in the prestige rank. We further observe the performance of paper M in the projection view. It is evident to find that most of cited papers (green points) are closely surrounding paper M (red point) except for several points, as shown in . The performance illustrates that citation structures of these cited paper are similar to paper M. These cited papers are likely to be influenced by paper M significantly in the process of retrieving related papers of high-quality. Therefore, the prestige score of paper M deserves to be increased (PR o =0.000780579, PR w =0.000786417), accompanying with a great improvement in its rank (Rank o =18, Rank w =10). Meanwhile, the prestige rank of paper N is decreased from 5th to 12th with an obvious decrease in scores. In contrast to paper M, there are many distant points in the projection view, which demonstrates obvious discrete distribution characteristics in . The similarity of citation structure among these papers is weak, which shows that the impact of paper N on these cited papers is very limited, although they referred to paper N. Consequently, the prestige score and rank of paper N drop significantly. It suggests that our weighted PageRank model based on citation network can achieve significant effects on the ranking of academic articles. bar chart largely enhances the readability of ranking results, in which the characteristics of articles' prestige scores are easily captured. Experts suggested that the proposed system realizes the academic influence analysis based on citation network, which is quite important for those who want to further find reliable references. One of the experts claimed that " The large scale of academic dataset causes the visual clutter. It becomes a common challenge to capture feature information in citation network quickly and intuitively. In this system, the distance of points in two-dimensional space is able to represent the features of corresponding papers in the high-dimensional semantic space, which largely enables users to observe the similarity of citation links in the citation network by means of a rather simple way."

Usability and Improvements: The experts also appreciated the visual designs of our system. For example, the ranking of articles prestige scores based on citation network is intuitively presented by means of bar charts. More details about citations and their contextual relationships are quickly displayed in the association views based on a rich set of interaction designs. They believe that the proposed system would play an important role in paper retrieval from a large scale of database. Moreover, they also provided some useful suggestions to help improve our system according to their domain knowledge. The first expert mentioned that " The publication time is an important factor for the evaluation of paper influence. How to scientifically integrate the publication time into the proposed model for further ranking optimization is still an interesting topic in the future work." The second expert mentioned that " In this system, nodes and links in citation network are considered as NPL items, and further trained and represented by means of word2vec. There are still some word embedding points located nearby in the projection view, the semantic features of which are hardly interpreted. How to improve people's understanding of current ranking results effectively and present the influence of citation relationships visually is still a difficult task."
A C C E P T E D
In order to further verify the effectiveness of the system, we invite two domain experts to use our system and collect their suggestions that are summarized as follows:

Visual Design and Interactions: In opinion of the experts, the system interface is well designed and displays a large amount of useful information for insights of the proposed ranking model and underlying dataset. The visual ranking system proposes an in-depth exploration of citation data through a rich set of convenient interactions and visual designs. With the help of representation learning model, massive citation links are represented as vectors, which is the basis of quantitative calculation of citation structure similarity. Meanwhile, citation networks can be visually presented and interactively explored for the cognition of context relationship of citations. A user-friendly design of

Despite of the advantages of our visual ranking for the academic influence of academic articles, there are still some problems not well resolved in our work, which would be further addressed in the future work. First, there are still a great deal of dissimilarities between citation relations and NLP terms, which might bring potential uncertainty for the ranking result of our method. In the future work, we will further explore the propagation of uncertainty for the uses of word2vec during each step in our ranking model. Meanwhile, an effective prediction task would be designed for those citation links with high-related association achieved by word2vec, which plays an important role in the evaluation of academic influence of articles. Second, the citation network is also highly related to the publication time of articles. For M A N U S C R I P T example, the article located in the middle part of the citation network will always present abundant semantic relationships, compared with those articles published in early or recent time periods. This might limits the accurate evaluation of article influence and bring some uncertainties to the visual ranking results. In the future work, we will integrate publication time into the PageRank model, which is able to optimize the ranking results and allow users to better explore and analyze the academic influence of different articles of interest.
pline of Zhejiang-A (Zhejiang University of Finance and EconomicsStatistics).

head._text: A C C E P T E D

p._text: PageRank is a widely-used evaluation model for the ranking of article influence, and bar charts are commonly applied to visualize the ranking of scholarly articles. However, information overloading is inevitably generated with the increasing size of dataset, which largely disturbs the evaluation of academic impact of articles. In this paper, we provide a visual analytic system for the ranking of large scale scholarly data. A representation learning model, word2vec, is applied to training the citation relationships, and the similarity of articles can be better characterized through vectorized representations. Then, a novel weighted PageRank model is established to evaluate the influence of cited papers, in which the similarity of citation networks is regarded as an important weight. At last, case studies based on real-world datasets, as well as the interviews with domain experts are provided to further demonstrate the effectiveness of our system in the visual ranking of academic influence via citation network.

head._text: M A N U S C R I P T A C C E P T E D

figDesc._text: The visualization interface is comprised of five primary views: (a) a ranking view, showing the result of ranking algorithms. (b) a projection view, that displays each article as a point and implies their citation similarity by means of distance. (c) an information view, presenting the essential information of an article of interest. (d) a network view, showing the direct and indirect citation links of articles. (e) a control panel allowing users to control and tune the damping factor and ranking model.
An analogy between the articles in citation network and natural language processing (NPL) terms.
The pipeline for the visual ranking of article influence via citation relationship.

The visual designs in the ranking view. There are three different conditions: (a) the initial status of ranking result of weighted PageRank, (b) the interactive state when a bar is clicked, (c) the comparison of different ranking result.

Citation network view, in which the articles are located in the parallel timelines with solid lines linking their cited articles, allowing users to better observe article similarity in the citation network. M A N U S C R I P T means of a curve. A palpable comparison is conducted to clearly show the performances of different sorting algorithms. Articles have con- siderable differences in the ranking results. The PR o represents the prestige scores in original PageRank model, while PR w is the values calculated by the weighted PageRank model. Moreover, PT indicates the publication time of articles.

The similarity in citation network. There are several closer given articles in picture (a), and then their similarity are discussed through comparing their citation networks which are displayed in picture (b), (c), (d).

The performance of different papers. The comparison of ranking results based on different sorting algorithms are shown in picture (a). The different performance of paper M and N is displayed in picture (b) and (c).
